column1: [1]-[1] [1] [1] (HITS; also known as [2] and [2]) is a [3] [3] algorithm that rates Web pages, developed by [4] [4].
column2:
1 - Hyperlink-Induced Topic Search
2 - hubs and authorities
3 - link analysis
4 - Jon Kleinberg
column5:
The idea behind Hubs and Authorities stemmed from a particular insight into the creation of web pages when the Internet was originally forming; that is, certain web pages, known as hubs, served as large directories that were not actually authoritative in the information that they held, but were used as compilations of a broad catalog of information that led users direct to other authoritative pages. In other words, a good hub represents a page that pointed to many other pages, while a good authority represents a page that is linked by many different hubs.

The scheme therefore assigns two scores for each page: its authority, which estimates the value of the content of the page, and its hub value, which estimates the value of its links to other pages.

column1: [1] [1] and [2] [2] developed PageRank at [3] [3] in [4] as part of a research project about a new kind of search engine.
column2:
1 - Larry Page
2 - Sergey Brin
3 - Stanford University
